qas.question: What is one huge advantage to using the black-box method?
What can black-box testing sometimes be referred to with the in-ability to see the code?

answers.text: like a walk in a dark labyrinth without a flashlight.

qas.question: What is a good reason to have testers and developers separate?

answers.text: tester likely has a different set and may emphasize different areas of functionality

qas.question: What knowledge is required for the black box technique?

plausible_answers.text: "like a walk in a dark labyrinth without a flashlight."

qas.question: Black-box coding has been compared to what?
Some parts of the program can remain untested because the what law is not examined?

plausible_answers.text: tester likely has a different set and may emphasize different areas of functionality

qas.question: Testers and developers are kept together for what reason?

context: One advantage of the black box technique is that <a0_0>no <b3_0>programming<b3_0/> knowledge is required<a0_0/>. Whatever biases the programmers may have had, the <a2_0><b6_0>tester likely has a different set and may emphasize different areas of functionality<b6_0/><a2_0/>. On the other hand, black-box testing has been said to be <b4_0>"<a1_0>like a walk in a dark labyrinth without a flashlight.<a1_0/>"<b4_0/> Because they do not examine the <b5_0>source<b5_0/> code, there are situations when a tester writes many test cases to check something that could have been tested by only one test case, or leaves some parts of the program untested.
